All in all, I'd give this game a 7.5 out of 10.

Before even playing this game, please note:
This game is not anything like its popular sequel, Postal 2.

The first Postal game is definitely the black sheep of the Postal series. Released in 1997, this game spiked immense controversy with its dark and gruesome style. Its a 3/4s isometric view style of game with prerendered backgrounds. One of my problems with the game is that the controls take some time to get used to. You can either use just your mouse to move and shoot, just your keyboard, or use the two together. Also with the angle, it can be tough to tell where your bullets are going to go and how you can hit enemies well. The graphics are pretty standard and use 3-d characters on top of prerendered backgrounds. It works quite well for a game like this. The game is about averagely long for a five dollar game, which is another thing I'd like to bring up; the price tag. While others may disagree with me, and you're free to, I believe a five-dollar price tag for this game is a bit much. It goes on sale often however, so I'd buy it when it's around one dollar, maybe slightly more.

Overall, I'd say this is an alright game. It knew exactly what it wanted to do and did it well. It's not the best in the Postal series, and may not be too long, but its an okay ride. Take it for what it's worth.   7.5/10

reviewText:
I like to classify this game as a psychological horror because it has a heavy emphasis on how disturbed the Postal Dude is, and the game's dark atmosphere and NPCs begging for their lives make massacre seem like a travesty rather than an accomplishment.  The game does at times have dark humor (especially in the Special Delivery expansion pack) that I'll admit I chuckled at, but it doesn't take away from the game's dark tone.  Originally the tank controls made the game more difficult, but as of this review an update giving it twin stick controls make it much more manageable.  Also, I really like the art style and the Postal Dude's voice.

It'd pain me to rate it on a scale so I'll just tell you that you should really buy it.

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: POSTAL
Genre: Action, Indie
Developer: Running With Scissors
Publisher: Running With Scissors
Release Date: 14 Nov, 1997

TL:DR At the bottom of the review

OverviewPostal is a Single Player shooter, it's also one of them games that even though it was made in 1997 it is still a fun game to play. It was the start of the Postal series, some may argue that this is the best one, while the others don't really like the old school graphics and the way the game is played. I myself personally love retro games, it really shows us how much we have developed through gaming history.

GameplayPostal hasn't really got that much too it via the gameplay. There isn't really any story line to the game, it's pretty self-explanatory when you first enter the game. What's your objective? Kill everyone. Yep that's right, your soul purpose in this game is to literally a certain pecentage of the population on that map in order to proceed. You'll find a variety of guns as you progress through each level, as they get more and more challenging as the game goes on. The controls are pretty basic, WSAD to move and the arrow keys to shoot in the direction you want to shoot. This kind of control scheme is so much better then using the mouse to point and shoot (in my opinion). You'll obviously have to dodge other police guards and other random people that will try to kill you at any cost, using rocket launchers, shotguns, machine guns ect. A small complaint I do have with this game is that if you get hit by a rocket launcher, then you fall on the ground. If the AI is smart he will continue to shoot rocket launchers at you before you can stand up, therefor killing you in a cheap sort of way. I'm not gonna say that this is a big complaint to make, as this game was made in 1997, but it's just something to keep in mind. Keep your distance. The variety of levels is rather nice as well, you may find yourself in a wide range of different locations, but with a not a lot of variety of enemies. I like the way that the game also has a quick reset, so that if you do die, or you feel like you have messed up then you can quickly and easily reset the game using space (by defult). This a nice feature to the game rather than waiting everytime for a laoding screen, losing the pacing of the game all together. That being said, this game is by no means easy, okay the first few levels are just a warm up to what you are going to encounter later of, with a large number of enemies attacking you from different sides, you can't simply just run into a area and kill them all. But this game is also by no means very strategic. I guess you could be, planning out what enemies you're going to kill that you see in the screen then going forth with that plan, but other than that it's not strategic at all, and that's perfectally fine for this type of game, a fast paced single player shooter.

GraphicsThe graphics of this game is obviously gonna be judged from the time that this game was made. 1997. Well I wasn't even born then so I don't really have a standard of what games should've looked like back then. Some of the graphics seem to stand out more than others, some of them are really well detailed and done. While some others look a bit out of place, what I mean by that is that some are nicely polished off, and then some just seem to be hand drawn and not bothered polishing off. I guess that must just be because of the time of when this game was made, but like I said I don't really have much to work on since I don't really have any 'standards' for what games where meant to look like in 1997. The characters look well done, and the animations are smooth.

Music & SoundThe game itself diesn't base around the music very much, sometimes you will find some levels don't have any music at all. There has obviously been a lot of time and effeort for the sound effects of this game, each gun having a different sound effect when you shoot and reload the weapon. There is obviously a lot of screaming and grunting as you are literally killing every living person you see. It works very well with the whole murder spree situation of the game just because you can.

Conclusion/TL:DRThe game itself evolves around you killing every living person you come across. While collecting a variety of different weapons that you can use to kill other people. The graphics are fairly good for the time I guess...? I don't really have a standard for what graphics where suppose to look like in 1997. You will soon realise there isn't much music to the game, but I'm sure you will be too busy murdering people for no apparent reason to care much about that. Smooth and well done animtations.

reviewText:
Postal is the first in the Postal series and it definetly stands out for being different from the rest in tone only. In my opinion this is one of my favorites in the series, infact it's my favorite third-person shooter game.

The story isn't that incredible and just there because there needs to be one, basically life in paradise is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and you are being evacted from your own house, you (The Postal Dude) think that there's a disease going around and you, you are the cure, you go on rampage with your shades and memorable one-liners to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up Paradise. That is basically the plot, although there's a diary entry in the manual.

The aim of the game is simple kill all the hostiles, and kill all bystandards (if desired). You are told to kill a certain amount of people, however it's best to kill everyone, after you kill everyone you press F1 to proceed, this is what confused a lot of people who didn't read the instructions, but funnily enough you get an achievment!
The game can become difficult as you progress, so it's good to take you time, however not only does the difficulty increase, so does your roster which becomes very useful in certain situations. You have a stock standard weapons roster,  but you'll be using the SMG the most since it has unlimited ammo.

As I said this game can be very difficult at times, which is why the gameplay becomes very strategical making you want to plan your moves, the game isn't as frustrating as for example: Hotline Miami, the game is the sort of difficulty you would expect from Quake, a game that influences POSTAL quite a bit and was definetly the type of game RWS were aiming for.

If you were a fan of the sequels, then you may be

This review might be offensive to some.

Introduction
Postal is a rightly controversial game by Running with Sisscors, it's balls to the walls grim and all about committing mass genocide for fun. A game of pure edginess that it makes Manhunt weep (kinda).

Gameplay
Isometric shoot 'em up with a focus on a variety of weapons used to painfully dispatch your opponents. Using the arrow keys or the mouse to move and shoot, X when you have committed the act of violence and they beg for your mercy, you can kill them with that X key. You must cull a certain percentage of the filth that roams in front of Earth and then hit F1 to continue to a next area requiring your cleansing.

Recommendations
The sound design for the game is a bit hammy (occasional humorous quips from Postal Dude) but works brilliantly in portraying a grimdark world in which you look through the eyes of a psychopathic serial killer. Alone that makes the game unique for it and recognizable.

Postal itself is litertally self-parody, mocking the absurdities of the gaming industry's reaction to ultra-violence and decadence. Dark humour is present and makes fun of your victims deaths proves this. Pretentious as all hell statement but I feel it works.

Simple control system makes it easy to play but hard to master.

reviewText:
coming from the age of doom, quake, and windows 95: postal 1 has something of an identify crisis brought on from the future of the series.

for starters:

if you looking for any of postal's attempts at risque or snarky humor in rws' first title, you'll find none of it here. this is the descent of one man's grasp on reality. the whole point of the game is to carry out your own personal genocide. there are no daily errands to accomplish. it's just you against the world.

this game is *dark*. the atmosphere is majorly different. something that appeals to me greatly is the ingame music. it sounds like the end result of merzbow collaborating with moozE or lustmord; loops of harsh noise and dark ambient soundscapes define what you hear, and this helps to make the game more distinctive in its presentation.

graphically, postal 1 has aged well.. sorta. the ingame engine works by rendering voxel models of NPCs and items on a drawn 2D background that is surprisingly well detailed, giving you a good reason to explore the maps. i'm not gonna lie - the voxel models look horrendous, but what can you expect from a game that's nearly 20 years old?

postal 1 is also a product of its age, with mixed results. the ingame control scheme feels overly clunky and primitive at worse, or mildly awkward at best. it takes some getting used to. if you guessed that rws tried to translate doom's way of moving about and shooting onto an isometric point of view, you wouldn't be too far off. whether if it works or not is up to your preferences. this is also reflected in the gameplay design: enemies will try to attack you from every angle. you have to master dodging to increase your chances of survival. if you don't, you will die. a lot.

can i advocate this game? yes, but you should know what to expect. postal 1 feels prehistoric in terms of production values today, but if you're into old games like me: you can forgive this. go shoot some people.

reviewText:
It doesn‚Äôt really have a plot (unless you have the booklet that came with the game in 1997 or the Dude‚Äôs little diary bits before each level). But for the kind of game that Postal is, it doesn‚Äôt really need one. It‚Äôs just mindless fun. And you know what, that‚Äôs okay. The game is played in a top down, isometric point of view (kind of like Sonic 3D Blast or Command & Conquer). This is actually pretty cool. The camera is neither too far away or too close. You have a good sense of where you are and where enemies are. So it‚Äôs not hard to plan things out. It‚Äôs best if you play the game tactically. There is however a drawback to the whole bird‚Äôs eye, isometric view. It‚Äôs a bit hard to line up your shots with an NPC. And it can get frustrating (especially when the NPCs move which they will do by the way). But it‚Äôs forgivable seeing as that it doesn‚Äôt take much to kill an NPC. You have a selection of about eight weapons. Your default weapon which is a weak assault rifle, a stronger assault rifle, a shotgun, a grenade, a missile launcher, a molotov cocktail, a flamethrower, and an RPG. You even get a few specialty weapons such as land mines.
You play as a character called The Dude. No, not Dude from The Big Lebowski but The Postal Dude. The only way I can describe The Postal Dude is that he‚Äôs a smoother, less muscular version of Duke Nukem. He also shouts catchphrases like Duke. Catchphrases Like ‚ÄúButtsauce‚Äù and ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be a sissy‚Äù. Though, he can also be described as a more tragic version of Duke Nukem as well. If you are following the games (almost non-existent) plot, it turns out that The Dude has gone insane and is under the impression that everyone in the city has a madness disease. So he takes it upon himself to exterminate everything that moves. I won‚Äôt give away the ending. But I will say that it is pretty satisfying.
So in conclusion, all I can say is that Postal is mindless fun. It‚Äôs really just a pick up and play game. It‚Äôs also a good way to relief stress after a grilling day at work or school.  This game gets the official Redneck grade of G for good.

reviewText: Postal is by far one of gaming's most brutal and possibly traumitizing titles. Released back in 1997 for the PC, it was full of violence, executions, and very disturbing imagery. It wouldn't be a stretch to call this the Silent Hill 2 of its era for how it could scar someone. Coming from the lighthearted and South Park-esque tone of Postal 2, this is a pretty jarring shift in tone. So if you were expecting the goofy tone of Postal 2 to have originated in this game, then this won't be for you.\n\nBut ignoring comparisons of Postal 2 and its tone for this review, Postal is a very enjoyable isometric shooter. The weapons (with the possible sole exception of the basic shotgun) are all very powerful and fun to use. The levels are cool to look at, even if the character models look like something out of Thief or System Shock 2. The game does provide a pretty good challenge with a variety of difficulty modes to choose from. My only complaints with the game lie with the removal of the multiplayer and level editor (the latter of which could have been great for Steam Workshop), as well as the short 4-5 hour campaign. But if you're looking for a darkly-toned stress reliever, then Postal is for you. It's cheap and very fun. While Postal 2 is certainly a step up from this one, Postal is still very enjoyable. Well as enjoyable as it can be with its dark tone.

A game custom-built for the Streisand effect. Unlike Postal 2 (which is a complete chore of a game, a circus clown who smeared his face in ketchup riding on your shoulders firing his gun into the air while beating you about the head with his collection of Garbage Pail Kids merchandise), the imagery really works here and I felt genuinely, horribly disturbed by it. Unfortunately the gameplay is 1996-style isometric bullcrap. You spin your character around to shoot the bros, take cover when they are shooting at you. There are civilians and it doesn't matter whether you shoot them or not, you just have to kill the ones with actual weapons. So the big darkness the Postal Dude is fighting is other people with guns, because he should have all the guns and not anyone else!

It only gets away with what it does because of its context, but not enough to warrant a recommendation.

The controls are a bit awkward, but once you wrap your head around the fact that ctrl is shoot and f is duck, it becomes a very successful anger management class. The reason I like POSTAL so much is because the levels all look like actual places, like a gas station or shopping mall, and are not just generic hallways and rooms seperating you from god-knows-what that is outside. POSTAL has very open levels with very few scripted events or cutscenes, but the AI is not suited for this at all. Instead of staying in one area, the npcs will either run away and force you to track them down, or home in on you like a heat-seeking missile. Another odd thing is the fact that you do not have to kill everybody, even if they are trying to kill you. You just press F1, and The Dude magically teleports to the next level. I recommend this game, but I suggest you only get it when it is on sale, or else you may be dissapointed.\n\nP.S. reviewText: I paid $0.99 for this game, and that is about as much as it is worth. The controls are a bit awkward, but once you wrap your head around the fact that ctrl is shoot and f is duck, it becomes a very successful anger management class. The reason I like POSTAL so much is because the levels all look like actual places, like a gas station or shopping mall, and are not just generic hallways and rooms seperating you from god-knows-what that is outside. POSTAL has very open levels with very few scripted events or cutscenes, but the AI is not suited for this at all. Instead of staying in one area, the npcs will either run away and force you to track them down, or home in on you like a heat-seeking missile. Another odd thing is the fact that you do not have to kill everybody, even if they are trying to kill you. You just press F1, and The Dude magically teleports to the next level. I recommend this game, but I suggest you only get it when it is on sale, or else you may be dissapointed.\n\nP.S. I heard the japanese levels do not work on this version of the game, so watch out for that.

Introduction
Back in the 90's, some elements in gameplay, art and level design were a huge impact in the video game industry. On a  early stage, some video games were backlashed due to incidents related to specific titles based on violence. POSTAL is a video game whose purpose is to understand the madness of a person, and it does great.

Sypnosis
In POSTAL you play as a man who thinks the world is infected by a outbreak of violence which is not identified, therefore he goes into a massive rampage looking for exterminate anyone infected.

Gameplay Analysis
Consist in a top-down camera feature that let you see any NPC visible on your perspective. The pattern system is pretty simple, you must defeat them in order to progress the game. There are some items which can help you to improve your rampage:

Item        Description                Medkit        It's available in specific parts of each map and some NPCs can drop it. The amount of points for each of them is 10 (The maximum of Health points is 200).                Bulletproof vest        This item isn't droped by any NPC in the game, it's only available in some parts of each map. The amount of points provided is 5 (The maximum of protection points is 10)                Ammo box        This item has an interesting behaviour, if you're full of ammo, the items that you can't collect just blow away from you like confetti                Weapons        According to your progress, they'll be unlocking and can be use in the next maps
In addition, POSTAL provides 17 maps (plus 4 additional maps as an expansion) regarding single player including a game mode called The Gauntlet Challange.  In this mode you have different tasks which make the game less repetive. There are 8 weapons and 3 tactical ones.

Running with Scissors (the developes behind this project) did a good job here, some audio effects such as Ambience sound, machinery noises, vehicles and animals were design in a way that fits the environment in the story, at some point it looks like an horror game (keeping in mind the intentions of the man known as POSTAL Dude" has).
